question: Riches-Cannieu anastomosis (RCA) anastomosis in the ____ between the {{c1::ulnar deep motor branch}} and ____ severe ____ nerve injury in the arm = weak forearm flexors & sparing of thenar muscles. severe ____ nerve injury in the arm = unexpected weakness of all intrinsic hand muscles (including thenar)
original_cloze:
Riches-Cannieu anastomosis (RCA) 

anastomosis in the {{c1::palm}} between the {{c1::ulnar deep motor branch}} and {{c1::re-current median branch}} 

severe {{c2::median}} nerve injury in the arm = weak forearm flexors & sparing of thenar muscles. 

severe {{c2::ulnar}} nerve injury in the arm = unexpected weakness of all intrinsic hand muscles (including thenar)

question: Radial n. course____ to the axillary artery. then, through the ____ (boarders made up of)under the ____ and between the ____ musclesalong the ____ before entering the anterior compartmentdescends between ____ medialy and ____ lateraly____ to the ____ the n. branches into the ____ and ____ in the forearm it passes between superficial and deep heads of the ____ muscle aka the ____
original_cloze:
Radial n. course

{{c1::posterior}} to the axillary artery.  then, through the {{c2::triangular interval}} (boarders made up of)

under the {{c8::teres major}} and between the {{c2::Lateral & Medial triceps::2}} muscles

along the {{c3::spiral groove}} before entering the anterior compartment

descends between {{c4::brachialis}} medialy and {{c4::brachioradialis}} lateraly

{{c5::anterior}} to the {{c5::lateral epicondyle}} the n. branches into the {{c6::PIN}} and {{c6::superficial radial}} 

in the forearm it passes between superficial and deep heads of the {{c7::supinator}} muscle aka the {{c7::arcade of Fröhse}}

question: suprascapular nerve. course originate from the C5 and C6 spinal nerve roots and contributes to the ____ which it branches off then passes the ____ of the neck and runs beneath the ____ to the superior margin of the scapula.It runs through the ____, to innervate the ____ The nerve then wraps around the ____, to innervate the ____
original_cloze:
suprascapular nerve. course 

originate from the C5 and C6 spinal nerve roots and contributes to the {{c1::upper trunk::plexus}} which it branches off 

then passes the {{c2::posterior triangle}} of the neck and runs beneath the {{c2::trapezius}} to the superior margin of the scapula.

It runs through the {{c3::suprascapular notch}}, to innervate the {{c5::supraspinatus}} 

The nerve then wraps around the {{c4::spinoglenoid notch}}, to innervate the {{c5::infraspinatus}}

muscle: Treatment of serratus anterior injury/injury to the long thoracic nerve: same 2 for both(a) acute stage, pain reduction and ROM exercise; (b) intermediate stage, passive stretching of the {{c1::rhomboids}}, {{c1::levator scapulae}}, and pectoralis minor; (c) late stage, strengthening exercise of all shoulder girdle muscles, including the trapezius.Treatment of trapezius palsy/injury to the spinal accessory nerve: Will involve physical therapy to adequately strengthen adjacent muscle groups, including {{c1::rhomboids}} and {{c1::levator scapulae}}.Surgical repair with a {{c2::dynamic muscle transfer}} is recommended if the patient fails conservative treatment.
question: Treatment of serratus anterior injury/injury to the long thoracic nerve: same 2 for both(a) acute stage, pain reduction and ROM exercise; (b) intermediate stage, passive stretching of the ____, ____, and pectoralis minor; (c) late stage, strengthening exercise of all shoulder girdle muscles, including the trapezius.Treatment of trapezius palsy/injury to the spinal accessory nerve: Will involve physical therapy to adequately strengthen adjacent muscle groups, including ____ and ____.Surgical repair with a ____ is recommended if the patient fails conservative treatment.
original_cloze:
Treatment of serratus anterior injury/injury to the long thoracic nerve: same 2 for both
(a) acute stage, pain reduction and ROM exercise; 
(b) intermediate stage, passive stretching of the {{c1::rhomboids}}, {{c1::levator scapulae}}, and pectoralis minor; 
(c) late stage, strengthening exercise of all shoulder girdle muscles, including the trapezius.

Treatment of trapezius palsy/injury to the spinal accessory nerve: 
Will involve physical therapy to adequately strengthen adjacent muscle groups, including {{c1::rhomboids}} and {{c1::levator scapulae}}.

Surgical repair with a {{c2::dynamic muscle transfer}} is recommended if the patient fails conservative treatment.

question: FEMORAL NERVE course: lumbar plexus, 2, 3, 4 ventral rami. within the substance of the ____. emerges in a groove between this muscle and the ____ and descends under the ____ beneath which, a branch courses behind the ____ to innervate the ____in the ____, n. lies on the iliacus m. lateral to the {{c4::femoral artery}}About ____ cm distal, it divides into 2 cutaneous n's The ____ divides to the sartorius and two cutaneous branches (intermediate and medial cutaneous n's of thigh) The ____ divides into the saphenous branch and rectus branches
original_cloze:
FEMORAL NERVE course: 

lumbar plexus, 2, 3, 4 ventral rami. within the substance of the {{c1::psoas major}}. 

emerges in a groove between this muscle and the {{c1::iliacus}} and descends under the {{c2::inguinal ligament}} 

beneath which, a branch courses behind the {{c3::femoral sheath}} to innervate the {{c3::pectineus m.}}

in the {{c4::femoral triangle}}, n. lies on the iliacus m. lateral to the {{c4::femoral artery}}

About {{c6::4}} cm distal, it divides into 2 cutaneous n's  

The {{c5::anterior division}} divides to the sartorius and two cutaneous branches (intermediate and medial cutaneous n's of thigh) 

The {{c5::posterior division}} divides into the saphenous branch and rectus branches

original_cloze:
exact cause of diabetic amyotrophy is unknown 

believed to result from a multifocal {{c1::immune-mediated microvasculitis::2 names}}.

amyotrophy has been noted to occur after {{c3::marked weight loss::pt characteristic}}

original_cloze:
Tibial nerve course 

descends along the popliteal fossa to the distal border of the {{c1::popliteus}} muscle, superficial to it 

proximally, it is positioned {{c3::lateral::side}} to the popliteal vessels, before crossing to the opposite side 

passes anterior to the {{c2::aponeurotic arch::landmark}} 
deep to the {{c2::soleus}} muscle, to enter the leg

in the distal one-third of the leg it is covered only by skin and fascia, sometimes overlapped by the {{c4::flexor hallucis longus}}

It reaches the {{c5::medial malleolus::bony structure}}, ending under the {{c5::flexor retinaculum}}

where it divides into medial and lateral {{c6::plantar}} nerves

to the region between the {{c4::lateral malleolus}} and the {{c4::calcaneus}}.

question: Common peroneal n. course curves laterally around the ____ of the ____, passing through a ____ opening in the ____ muscle. deep peroneal n. passes in between the ____ m. and ____ m.at the ankle, divides into the ____ branch to supply the extensor digitorum brevis and the ____ branch to the 1st interspace superficial peroneal n. runs between the ____ and ____ musclesand emerges at lower ____ of the leg, where it divides into lateral and medial terminal which are sensory

curves laterally around the {{c1::neck}} of the {{c1::fibula}},

question: Low-Rate Repetitive Stimulation:This repetitive stimulation test is performed at a rate of ____ to ____ HzEach stimulus causes the ____ amplitude to drop. If the ____ is decreased, the potential will fall below the threshold necessary for activation. This results in a decrease of the ____ amplitude
original_cloze:
Low-Rate Repetitive Stimulation:

This repetitive stimulation test is performed at a rate of {{c1::2}} to {{c1::3}} Hz

Each stimulus causes the {{c2::EPP}} amplitude to drop. 

If the {{c2::safety factor}} is decreased, the potential will fall below the threshold necessary for activation. 

This results in a decrease of the {{c3::MUAP}} amplitude

question: Low-Rate Repetitive Stimulation:An abnormality is considered when a CMAP demonstrates >____% amplitude reduction between the ____ and ____ waveformsAn increase in waveform can be seen if more stimulations are provided due to mobilization of ____A typical ____ decrement can be seen in myasthenia gravis
original_cloze:
Low-Rate Repetitive Stimulation:

An abnormality is considered when a CMAP demonstrates >{{c1::10}}% amplitude reduction between the {{c2::1st}} and {{c2::4th}} waveforms

An increase in waveform can be seen if more stimulations are provided due to mobilization of {{c3::secondary ACh stores}}

A typical {{c4::U-shaped}} decrement can be seen in myasthenia gravis

question: ____:After a decrement is noted with LRRS, a 30-60 second ____ or ____ stimulation (50 Hz) should be performed. demonstrates a repair in the CMAP amplitude with an immediate follow up LRRS because of an improvement in neuromuscular transmission.
original_cloze:
{{c1::Postactivation Facilitation (PAF)}}:

After a decrement is noted with LRRS, a 30-60 second {{c2::isometric contraction}} or {{c3::tetany-producing}} stimulation (50 Hz) should be performed. 

demonstrates a repair in the CMAP amplitude with an immediate follow up LRRS because of an improvement in neuromuscular transmission.

question: ____:This response is seen as a CMAP amplitude decreases. It occurs with a ____ performed every ____ for ____ after an initial 30-60-second isometric contractionThis test should be used if a ____ is not seen with the initial ____, but a diagnosis of a NMJ disorder is suspected
original_cloze:
{{c1::Postactivation Exhaustion (PAE)}}:

This response is seen as a CMAP amplitude decreases. 

It occurs with a {{c2::LRRS::same}} performed every {{c3::minute}} for {{c3::5 minutes}} after an initial 30-60-second isometric contraction

This test should be used if a {{c2::decrement}} is not seen with the initial {{c2::LRRS::same}}, but a diagnosis of a NMJ disorder is suspected

question: High-Rate Repetitive Stimulation:repetitive stimulation test is performed at a rate of ____ to ____ Hz. It causes an accumulation of calcium in the cell, which assists ____ and repairs the waveformstypically performed if a patient is unable to perform a ____ ____
original_cloze:
High-Rate Repetitive Stimulation:

repetitive stimulation test is performed at a rate of {{c1::10}} to {{c2::50}} Hz. 

It causes an accumulation of calcium in the cell, which assists {{c3::ACh release}} and repairs the waveforms

typically performed if a patient is unable to perform a {{c4::30- to 60-second::time}} {{c4:: maximal isometric contraction}}

question: Single Fiber EMG Paramters____:caused by a increased delay in the ____ ____ of two muscle fibers belonging to the same motor unit (normally 10 to 60 μsec) Disorders of neuromuscular transmission affect the safety factor and cause a delay in the time for an EPP to reach threshold for a muscle fiber AP, Reinnervation through collateral sprouting after a nerve injury results in poor activation of the immature NMJs

{{c1::Recruitment interval (RI)}}:

This is the {{c2::interspike interval (in milliseconds)}} between two discharges of the {{c2::(same) 1st MUAP}} when {{c2::a second MUAP begins to fire}}. 

It is initiated by an increase in the force of a contraction. Normal is considered approximately {{c3::100}} msec

muscle: Decreased RI (Increased RF):would be consistent with a {{c1::neuropathic process}}

original_cloze:
{{c4::Recruitment ratio (RR)}}:

This has been used to represent recruitment capabilities, especially when a patient demonstrates difficulty in controlling a contractile force. 

It is calculated by dividing the {{c1::Firing Rate}} of the {{c1::first MUAP}} by the {{c2::number of different MUAPs on the screen}}. 

The normal RR is considered <{{c3::10}}

question: ____ PatternsThis is a qualitative or quantitative description of the sequential appearance of MUAPs.It is the electrical activity recorded from a muscle during ____. It is composed of ____ plus ____.It can be decreased in ____ and ____.
original_cloze:
{{c4::Interference}} Patterns

This is a qualitative or quantitative description of the sequential appearance of MUAPs.

It is the electrical activity recorded from a muscle during {{c1::a maximum voluntary contraction}}. 

It is composed of {{c2::recruitment}} plus {{c2::activation}}.

It can be decreased in {{c3::CNS diseases}} and {{c3::poor patient cooperation (pain, hysteria)}}.
